title: Python as an Engineering Tool
text:
Asking questions and getting help

If you have general questions about a topic, please raise your hand to ask it.
For more specific questions about issues you are having individually, please use the sticky notes to indicate whether you are on track or need help.

title: Python as an Engineering Tool

Schedule
Friday: Project presentation (9 AM - noon)

title: Python as an Engineering Tool
text:
What will this course cover?

Python basics
Python for plotting
Python for data analysis
Time series analysis
Building dashboards
Python for machine learning
Natural language processing

title: Python as an Engineering Tool
text:
Project

3-person teams (self sign up on the etherpad)
Your team will choose your own topic and data sets (that showcases what you learned) 
You are required to use Python and Jupyter notebooks.
You will work on your project on Thursday afternoon.
You will make a 12-min presentation followed by a Q&A.

Each team member are expected to speak for roughly even amount of time.

Submit your presentation slides and reproducible code on Canvas by Friday 5:00 PM.

title: Python as an Engineering Tool
text:
Project

The presentation should cover the following parts

Introduction or background
Projects objectives
Methods (e.g., data set description)
Results
Discussions (e.g., implications of the results, study limitations)
Key conclusions

title: Python as an Engineering Tool
text:
Project grading rubrics

Content (40%)

The work demonstrated good knowledge of the course content and skills.
The methods, results, and discussions were correct and appropriate.
The presentation utilized materials including visuals to effectively communicate the work with the audience.

title: Python as an Engineering Tool
text:
Project grading rubrics

Organization (20%)

The project was clearly and logically presented.
The transitions and flow were easy to follow.

title: Python as an Engineering Tool
text:
Project grading rubrics

Presentation (20%) - this will be graded individually

The speaker was fluent and had clear articulation on the topic.
The speaker made frequent eye-contact with the audience.
The materials were presented in a way that held audience attention.
The presentation did not significantly exceed the time allotment.

title: Python as an Engineering Tool
text:
Project grading rubrics

Code submissions (20%)

Complete code, data, and other necessary files were provided so that the instructors are able to reproduce all your work.
The codes in the Jupyter notebook were well organized and easy to read.

title: Python as an Engineering Tool
text:
Presentation checklist

Are the texts in your slides and plots/tables too small for the audience to read?
Are the plot axis clearly labeled and with units? 
Are there discussions on the study limitations?
Any work (e.g., images) from others need to be cited.
